_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Chlorine is the most commonly used substance for disinfecting drinking water.  The addition of chlorine or chlorine compounds to water is called chlorination.  Chlorination is considered to be the most important process for preventing the spread of waterborne disease in drinking water.  The Los Angeles Department of Water and Power (DWP) also stores and uses chlorine for drinking water disinfection purposes to protect public health per state and federal water quality standards.  Storing and handling large quantities of chlorine can create hazardous situations.  DWP takes safety obligations in storing and using chlorine as seriously as it takes providing safe drinking water.  DWP operates the Upper Stone Canyon Chlorination Station (USCCS), which is a chlorination facility that stores and uses anhydrous chlorine for disinfection purposes.  A Risk Management Plan (RMP) for the Upper Stone Canyon Chlorination Station was prepared and submitted to the United States Environment Protection Agency (EPA) and to the local Administering Agency (AA), city of Los Angeles Fire Department (LAFD), in June 2004, which was updated in November 2007. Subsequent to the November 2007 update of the RMP, the LADWP completed the chlorination station improvement project, which was in progress since 2004.  As part of this improvement project, the bulk chlorine storage tank was taken out of service, and the chlorination station started storing chlorine in one-ton containers.  A 4,700-lb capacity, dry media chlorine scrubber was also been installed at the Chlorination station. The above changes have further enhanced the safety of the chlorination station and will further mitigate offsite consequences of an accidental chlorine release. The chlorination station with ton containers and the scrubber system became operational in March 2008. This document is an update of the November 2007 RMP for the Upper Stone Canyon Chlorination Station. 

As mentioned above, the DWP Upper Stone Canyon Chlorinati

on Station chlorine handling process is subject to the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Risk Management Program and Plan and also to the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program requirements.  These Programs require a summary in the Risk Management Plan (RMP) of policies and procedures followed to safely operate the facility, including a description of the possible consequences in case of an accident and the actions, which will be taken by the facility in an event of an emergency.  The following information is specifically required in the RMP Executive Summary:

* Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies.
* General facility and regulated substances information.
* Offsite consequence analysis results.
* Summary of the accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps.
* Five-year accident history summary.
* Emergency response program summary.
* Planned changes to improve safety.

The above information for the Upper Stone Canyon Chlorination Station is provided below.

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The DWP accidental release prevention policy involves a unified approach that integrates the use of proven technology, trains staff in operation and maintenance practices, and uses tested and proven management system practices.  All applicable requirements of the State of California and EPA's Prevention Program are adhered to, including key elements such as training, systems management, and emergency response procedures.

The DWP emergency response policy involves the preparation of emergency response plans for hazardous materials, which are tailored to each facility and to the emergency response services available in the community, and is in compliance with the EPA and CalARP Program Emergency Response Program Requirements.  The Upper Stone Canyon Chlorination Station has prepared an Emergency Response Plan for Hazardous Materials to facilitate coordination and emerg

ency planning with offsite response officials and facilities in the event of an emergency.  The emergency response plan has been coordinated with local response agencies (City of Los Angeles Fire Department).  DWP employees respond to chlorine emergencies at the facility.

General Facility and Regulated Substance Information

The Upper Stone Canyon Chlorination Station is located at 1900 North Stone Canyon Road in Los Angeles, California.  There are multiple chlorine feed points on the reservoir complex property to disinfect water in Upper and Lower Stone Canyon Reservoirs, the Upper Stone Canyon bypass pipelines #1 and #2, and the membrane filtration plant.  The treated waters are piped into the distribution network, which serves parts of west Los Angeles with potable water.  The station building consists of a chlorine storage room, chlorine equipment room, an electrical equipment room, several chemical storage rooms, and a 4,700-lb capacity dry media scrubber room.  The facility stores chlorine, a regulated toxic substance under the EPA and CalARP Program rules.  The Upper Stone Canyon facility stores a maximum of 22 one-ton chlorine containers.  Ten of these containers can be connected to the chlorination process to feed chlorine liquid or gas.  The maximum quantity of chlorine present at the Upper Stone Canyon Chlorination Station at any given time exceeds the listed threshold quantities in the EPA and CalARP rules.  It also exceeds the listed threshold quantities in the federal and California Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) Standards.  However, the facility is normally unmanned and water treatment operators visit the facility daily and respond to any trouble alarms, which may occur.  Thus, the DWP Upper Stone Canyon facility is not subject to federal or California OSHA PSM regulations.

The design incorporates two banks of 4 one ton-containers each, which normally feed liquid chlorine to evaporators.  There i

s an automatic switchover system that determines which liquid chlorine header feeds the evaporators.  This system consists of a control panel, two motorized ball valves, and a pressure switch on the liquid header before the evaporators.  When the pressure in the liquid chlorine supply line drops to 20 psi, the switchover system opens the valve isolating the standby bank of ton containers to allow liquid chlorine to flow.  At the same time, it closes the ball valve on the now empty bank of ton containers.

The system is also configured with gas headers for each of the two banks of 4 one ton-containers.  This is essentially a complete gas feed system with automatic switchover capability.  It can be used during periods of low chlorine demand, or if the liquid system is out of service for repairs.  It is being provided because of the uncertainty of operations at this site in the future.

Since the normal operation is by withdrawing liquid chlorine, and the evaporators are equipped with motorized vacuum regulating valves downstream, it is possible for the gas supply to the chlorinators to be automatically shut off at the vacuum-regulating valve.  These valves can close upon a low temperature condition in the evaporator or at the valve, or upon power failure.  For this reason, in order to assure no interruptions of chlorine feed, a third bank of two one-ton containers is provided.  These two one-ton containers connect to a gas header which leads to three automatic switchover type vacuum regulating valves in parallel acting as an automatic backup gas supply.  The vacuum regulating valves have a capacity of 3,000 ppd each, for a total feed capacity of 9,000 ppd.  The valves open automatically based on a high vacuum condition that pulls the valve out of its detent position.  Since this is a mechanical setting on each separate valve, and the settings are not exactly the same, it is likely that not all of the valves will open at once.  One would open, followed by a second and

then a third if the feed demand is great enough.  With only two one-ton containers supplying this gas manifold, the sustainable gas feed rate is only about 800 ppd.  Therefore, when it comes on line it must be considered an emergency supply only.  A quick response from an operator is needed to come to the station and either get the liquid system back on line, or else start shedding chlorine feed (such as shore feeds) to a rate that can be sustained from two gas containers.  Other options include placing one or both of the primary banks of four one-ton containers each on their gas header systems.  The idea is that this emergency backup is intended for only an hour or so of feed before intervention.

A dry media type chlorine gas scrubber system is installed at the station.  The unit is actuated by chlorine detectors at a chlorine concentration of 3 ppm.  The scrubber can neutralize up to 4,700 lbs of chlorine in case of a chlorine leak.  The scrubber draws suction from the chlorine ton container and chlorinator rooms through a duct.  The station is equipped with an uninterruptible power supply (UPS) in addition to a backup power generator.  Therefore, in case of the failure of regular power, the scrubber will be functional.

All of the one-ton containers connected to the process are equipped with Halogen Systems valve actuators which shut the ton container valves when desired.  The current plan calls for closing all eight ton-containers (two banks of four each) that are connected to either the liquid or gas headers when any of the chlorine gas sensors in the chlorine tank or chlorinator rooms detect gas exceeding 3 ppm.  The scrubber system starts simultaneously.

The emergency backup gas supply (two one-ton containers) is equipped with Halogen Systems valve actuators, but they do not close automatically upon sensing a chlorine leak.  They remain open until an operator on site presses one of the red mushroom switches to close all of the valves (total of 10).  These t

wo one-ton containers normally remain in service during a chlorine leak (or false alarm) to prevent loss of disinfection to the distribution system (unless shut by the above described action).  The total capacity of these containers would limit the total release to no more than two tons (if the leak happens to be in this system), which the scrubber system is designed to handle.  Responding operators would determine if these two tons should be isolated, and they take the appropriate action.

The chlorinators supply gaseous chlorine to each of the Upper, the two bypass lines, the Lower, and the membrane filtration plant injection systems.  Chlorine gas is withdrawn from the chlorinators under vacuum to the injectors.  In the injectors, chlorine mixes with a high-pressure water supply to form a concentrated solution.  The chlorine solution discharged from the injector is diffused into the pipelines or the reservoir through multiple diffuser nozzles.  The Stone Canyon Complex injection system has eighteen injectors spread out among seven vaults, each located at a various location throughout the complex.

Seven chlorine leak detectors are provided in the station to detect chlorine leaks.  The detectors draw samples from the chlorine container and chlorinator rooms, as well as from the scrubber inlet and outlet ducts.  The detectors signal an alarm by activating a flashing red light over the entry door to the building, as well as an audible alarm within the container and chlorination rooms, and activating an alarm at the Los Angeles Aqueduct Filtration Plant (LAAFP) at Sylmar.  Also, the chlorine injector vaults are equipped with chlorine leak sensors.

Process control is by a programmable controller, which determines the feed rate based on the water flow rate and the chlorine residual.  There are flow meters transmitting flow signals to the controller.  Chlorine residual analyzers continuously monitor the treated water residuals.

In the event power is lost at the chlori

ne facilities, an alarm will alert the LAAFP control room.  Chlorine flow will continue unaffected, with no safety consequences.

The facility is normally unmanned; water treatment operators visit the facility daily. A response team coordinated from DWP Los Angeles Aqueduct Filtration Plant (LAAFP) responds to any trouble alarms, which may occur. Access to the facility is through gates, which are kept locked all the time.

Summary of the Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

The DWP accidental release prevention program is based on the following key elements:

* Detailed management system and clear levels of responsibilities and team member roles.
* Comprehensive safety information that is readily available to staff, emergency responders, and contractors.
* Comprehensive preventive maintenance program.
* Performance of hazard review of equipment and procedures with operation and maintenance staff participation and review.
* Use of state-of-the-art process and safety equipment.
* Use of effective operating procedures, written with the participation of the operators.
* High level of training of the operators and maintenance staff.
* Implementation of an incident investigation, inspection, and auditing program using qualified staff.

Chemical-specific prevention steps include availability of self-contained breathing apparatus (SCBA), worn by the operators during connection/disconnection of chlorine supply, awareness of the hazardous and toxic properties of chlorine, presence of chlorine detectors with remote monitoring, the use of a Halogen valve actuators mounted on the connection to the ton containers, and a scrubber.

Safety Information

Comprehensive chemical data has been assembled to include regulatory reporting and action thresholds, health hazard, and chemical exposure limitations, as well as detailed physical properties of chlorine.  This information includes chlorine background information and MSDS sheets.

Equipment sa

fety information was compiled on the chlorine process.  Specifications for the chlorine process are collected and provided in one place for easy reference.  Details such as maximum intended inventory; safe upper and lower temperatures; and safe upper and lower pressures for the chlorination facility are on file at the facility.  DWP also has procedures in place that are triggered to update safety information if there is a major change that makes existing information inaccurate.

Hazard Review 

A hazard review of the Upper Stone Canyon Chlorination Station was performed in March 2002 after the system design was completed.  In addition, a review of the March 2002 hazard review was performed on August 1, 2008.  This review served to verify that the hazard review is consistent with the current process, which became fully operational in July 2008 after extensive construction delays. It will be updated again within a five-year period or prior to a major change in the process.  Based on the March 2002 hazard review, 30 recommended actions were identified to improve the safety of the chlorine system.  These recommendations were evaluated and implemented. Based on the August 2008 hazard review, six additional recommendations were made. These recommendations are under evaluation and it is expected that they will be   implemented by December 2008. 

Seismic design of the chlorination station building was based on the 1999 version of the City of Los Angeles Building Code, which incorporates the 1997 Uniform Building Code.  Also considered were the site-specific response spectra for the project.  A memo dated November 13, 2006 from Michael Truong describes how the design complies with the January, 2004 CalARP seismic guidance document.  The seismic design criteria related to the equipment installation was included in the construction specifications.  Contractor submittals were required and included evaluations of meeting the seismic design criteria.  Each submittal was reviewed

by LADWP Engineering personnel to make sure the proposed equipment installation met the seismic design requirements.  Seismic concerns were therefore incorporated into the design and as each piece of equipment was evaluated for installation.  No additional recommended actions resulted from the engineering review or from the seismic walkthrough performed in February, 2007.

Operating Procedures

DWP has prepared written operating procedures for the Upper Stone Canyon chlorination facility, that provide clear instructions or steps for safely conducting activities relating to chlorination process.  They are consistent with the chlorine safety information. Written operating procedures included in the facility?s Operation and Maintenance Manual for Chlorination Stations include:

* Loading and unloading of ton containers.
* Container connection and disconnection.
* Initial startup.
* Normal operation.
* Normal shutdown.
* Temporary operation.
* Emergency operation.

DWP will update the operating procedures reflecting any major change in the process at the chlorination station.  DWP will further update the operating procedures to reflect current safe operating practices and configuration at the new Upper Stone Canyon facility.

Training 

The DWP ensures that each employee operating or maintaining the chlorination process, and each employee newly assigned to this process, is trained and tested for competency in the operating procedures listed above.  The DWP employee training documentation files include training records for each employee assigned to operate or maintain the chlorination process. The training ensures that the employee has the required knowledge, skills, and abilities to safely carry out the duties and responsibilities, including chlorine emergency response, as provided in the operating procedures.  Employee training includes as a minimum the following elements:

* Safety Information;
* Process Technology and Process Equipment, including safety systems;
* M

aintenance Procedures;
* Operating Procedures for the chlorine system;
* RMP Program contents; and
* Emergency Response Plan and Procedures.

Refresher training is provided at least every three years to each employee operating the chlorination process to ensure that the employee understands and adheres to the current operating procedures.  In addition, DWP ensures that operators are trained in any updated or new procedures prior to startup of a process after major modifications.

Maintenance 

The DWP operates a Maximo Program that generates a task order for performance of the preventive maintenance routine after a designated time past the closing of the previous task order for that maintenance.  Description of the work to be performed is included with the printed work order.  The Maintenance Supervisor is responsible for this task.  

In addition, the written maintenance procedure is provided in the General Operation and Maintenance Manual as follows: Preventive maintenance schedules are provided which summarize inspection, test, and maintenance schedules on a daily, weekly, monthly, biannual, annual, every 2 to 10 years, and as-needed basis.  These allow the operator to rapidly review what maintenance is necessary.  The schedules are supplemental to the log sheets on-site and provide a summary and quick reference to manufacturer's O&M manuals.  A maintenance log book is provided on-site for quick reference by the Operator. 

DWP documents inspection, testing, and maintenance of chlorination equipment and assures the performance is done in accordance with the recommendations of the manufacturer and industry groups (i.e., Chlorine Institute).

Internal Compliance Audits

The DWP certifies every three years (or earlier) that compliance with Prevention Program requirements is met and that procedures and practices developed are adequate and being followed.

The compliance audit consists of separating the RMP program elements or sections, and auditing each element to de

termine compliance and effectiveness.  For each internal audit, the audit team completes a Compliance Audit Certification Page and a Compliance Audit Checklist.  The Compliance Audit Certification Page provides process identification, the dates of the audit, team members, and certification by the audit leader and the Plant Manager.  The Compliance Audit Checklist details the requirements of each RMP element and contains questions that may assist with the auditing process. The audit checklist for each element consists of the following three sections:

* Records Review: A review of the RMP written Prevention Program.
* On-Site Conditions: The audit team reviews the program elements based on observation of the plant conditions and safety practices.
* Interviews:  The program elements are evaluated by interviewing personnel from appropriate functions including operations, maintenance, management, and contractors.

Team members record RMP program deficiencies identified during the audit on the checklist.

Incident Investigation

The DWP incident investigation procedures describe incident reporting, investigation, and investigation reporting steps to be followed by plant personnel.  The incident investigation is started promptly but no later than 48 hours after the event.  The DWP promptly addresses and resolves all recommendations and implements the recommendations in a timely manner to prevent an incident recurrence.  All incident investigation reports are retained on DWP file for at least a period of five years from the date the reports are completed.

Five-year Accident History Summary

An accidental minor chlorine release occurred at the Upper Stone Canyon Chlorination Station in April, 2007.  This accident occurred inside the chlorinator room and one operator suffered from chlorine gas inhalation.  The operator was treated for chlorine inhalation.  There were no onsite or offsite deaths.  Also, there were no offsite injuries and no evacuation actions were required.

Emergency Response Program Summary

DWP is a first responder, its employees respond to chlorine accidental releases.  Depending on the severity of the accidental release, external resources such as the City of Los Angeles Fire Department may be solicited to aid in handling a chlorine release.

As part of the emergency response program, the DWP has developed and implemented an emergency response plan for the purpose of protecting public health and the environment.  The following elements are included:

(a) An emergency response plan, maintained at the stationary source and at the Los Angeles Aqueduct Filtration Plant (LAAFP) containing:

* Organizational structure (chain-of-command) and responsibilities of various DWP personnel.
* Procedures for planning and coordination with off-site emergency response organizations.
* Details of the training programs for all employees involved with the chlorination process, contractor training, and medical surveillance of DWP personnel who respond to chlorine releases.
* Details of emergency recognition and prevention at the DWP.
* Procedures for informing the public and local emergency response agencies about accidental releases.
* Documentation of proper first aid and emergency medical treatment necessary to treat accidental human exposures and the detailed information on emergency health care.
* Procedures and measures for emergency response after an accidental release.

(b)    Procedures for the use of emergency response equipment and for its inspection, testing, and maintenance. 

(c)    Training in relevant procedures for all employees involved with the chlorination process.

(d)    Procedures to review and update, as appropriate, the emergency response plan to reflect changes and ensure that employees are informed of changes.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

A hazard review of the Upper Stone Canyon Chlorination Station was performed on March 26, 2002, after the system design was completed.  The hazard review was performed using

the Hazard and Operability (HAZOP) technique and covered both equipment and main procedures used for the chlorination process. Based on the March 2002 hazard review, a number of recommended actions were made to improve the safety of the chlorination system.  A number of equipment and procedural changes were made as part of the implementation of the recommended actions. 

In addition, a review of the March 2002 hazard review was performed on August 1, 2008.  This review served to verify that the hazard review is consistent with the current process, which became operational in July 2008 after extensive construction delays.  Based on the August 2008 hazard review, six additional recommendations were made. These recommendations are under evaluation and it is expected that they will be   implemented by December 2008.
